title: Market overview: FTSE ends lower on China worries
text:
4.47 0.00 
LONDON (ShareCast) - (ShareCast News) - 1630 (close): The FTSE 100 ended down 1.68% to 5,979.20 as China's economic slowdown continued to weigh on investors' minds. The People's Bank of China (HKSE: 3988-OL.HK - news ) said today it would pump 140 billion yuan into the financial system through a short-term liquidity adjustment operation. The move follows the central bank's decision on Tuesday to cut interest rates for the third time since November. However, the measures failed to soothe worries about the shrinking economy when sent global stocks tumbling on "Black Monday". On the upside, data showed a pick up in UK mortgage lending and approvals while the US enjoyed a unexpected increase in US durable goods orders. Company-wise Weir Group, RBS (LSE: RBS.L - news ) and ARM Holdings (LSE: ARM.L - news ) rallied while WPP (LSE: WPP.L - news ) slumped. 
1557: Instability in global capital markets makes the case for a September interest rate hike by the US central bank less compelling NY Fed president William Dudley says. 
1545: Barclays (LSE: BARC.L - news ) has reinstated its overweight recommendation on shares of IAG and 750p target price. After a rigorous benchmarking analysis and on the basis of bottom-up forecasts for all four group airlines, the broker finds that the company will hit the top end of its 10-14% target range for 2016-20 EBIT margins as soon as next year. 
1425: Analysts believe the latest report on US durable goods points to a stronger GDP growth than previously expected. "The July durable goods report means that business investment in equipment for the second quarter was a little better than the 4.1% annualised decline in the BEA's advance GDP report," said Steve Murphy US economist at Capital Economics. "Accordingly, more evidence suggesting that Q2 GDP growth will be revised up from 2.3% to above 3%. Q3 GDP growth still on track for a solid 2.5% gain." 1335: Orders for US durable goods grew more than expected last month, figures released on Wednesday showed. According to the Commerce Department, orders for long-lasting goods rose 2% in July compared with the 0.6% reading analysts had forecast. Excluding transportation, however, orders rose 0.6%, while orders for core capital goods rose 2.2% to reach their highest level in 13 months. 
1200: Applications for US home mortgages grew last week, data released on Wednesday showed. The Mortgage Bankers Association (MBA) said its seasonally adjusted index of application activity, which covers home purchase demand and refinancing demand, climbed 0.2% in the week ended 21 August. The seasonally adjusted sub-index of refinancing applications fell 1%, while the index of loan requests for home purchases, a key indicator of home sales, rose 1.7%. 
1100: The CBI´s distributive trades total sales index jumped to a reading of 24 in August, after printing at 21 in the month before (consensus: 18). 
1054: "For now, bond markets should focus on the wave of deflation pressures hitting the global economy with expectations of more BoJ easing and higher potential for ECB QE2, alongside question marks for Fed/BOE lift-off. Long term, concerns from China redrawing the financial landscape & lower reserves should be respected," analysts at Citi write today. 
1020: Across Britain, Wales saw a 29% quarter-on-quarter surge in loans to first time buyers and a 15% increase in loan to home movers from the previous three months, while remortgage loans rose 9% on a quarterly basis and 16% year-on-year. Northern Ireland saw a 15% quarter-on-quarter increase in both loans to first time buyers and home movers, while remortgage loans jumped 33% from the corresponding period in 2014, while Scotland registered a 14% increase in loan to home movers from the previous quarter. Remortgage loans north of the border grew 15% quarter-on-quarter and 21% year-on-year, while loans to first time buyers surged 52% from the previous quarter and 11% from the corresponding period in 2014. 
1000: According to the Council of Mortgage Lenders (CML), first-time buyers in London borrowed £2.67bn in the second three months of the year, representing a 12% increase from the previous quarter but a 10% year-on-year drop. Loans for home movers rose 14% quarter-on-quarter to £2.84bn but were down 9% from the corresponding period in 2014, while remortgage loans jumped 13% from the previous three months and 12% year-on-year to £3.24bn. 
0930: UK mortgage applications jumped in July, in sign a that the property market is continuing to thrive. The British Bankers Association said mortgage approvals in July grew 15% higher than a year ago, with house purchases rising 11% and re-mortgaging almost up 29%. "Savvy homeowners are snapping up competitive deals before an expected increase in interest rates," said BBA chief economist Richard Woolhouse. 
0842: Stocks have started the morning moving lower, with the miners and financials such as Aberdeen Asset Management (Other OTC: ABDNF - news ) and 3i acting as a drag, as some investors are waiting for the proverbial "other shoe" to drop in China. In particular, the recent heavy volatility has given many investors pause for thought, especially what some observers have called the 'air pockets' seen in the prices of many securities. Markets are expected to focus today on speeches from ECB chief economist Peter Praet and New York Fed president William Dudley. The latest US durable goods orders figures will also be closely watched. FTSE 100 down 107.88 points to reach 5,973.46.
